Testing LLMs in RAG is hard - is failure due to retrieval (top-k) or synthesis (LLM)?

activity.text:
Using top-k lookup for retrieval in your RAG system is fast but imprecise ü§î

Using cross-encoding as a reranking step can dramatically speed up LLM inference time AND improve accuracy! ‚ö°Ô∏è

Here's how to implement it in @llama_index üëá: https://t.co/CCfEzs5LOH https://t.co/1sTfq9M0c2

But with cross-encoding based reranking/pruning, the LLM synthesis takes 4 seconds, and the answer is better.

We use an MSMarco SBERT cross-encoder from @huggingface. 

Huge s/o to @jon_chuang for adding this feature.

Notebook: https://t.co/Pclt2AI0Bg https://t.co/9EJVHR4Oyr

replyTo.text:
We can use cross-encoding as a *reranking step* AFTER  existing top-k lookup. This allows you to set a much larger top-k for retrieval when building an LLM QA system.

In @llama_index, if you set top_k=10, by default LLM will take ~30 seconds. https://t.co/Q18umZj6b6

We ran a fun little agent benchmark comparing LLMs on their ability to use simple/toy tools.
üß† LLMs: GPT-3, ChatGPT, GPT-4, Claude v1 and v2 models
‚òëÔ∏è Tasks: calculating numbers, or ‚Äúdialing‚Äù a person.

Claude-2 is not far behind GPT-4. Take a look here!

https://t.co/taJX9IPu3N https://t.co/ZoK9H6mKsb

The full set of tasks:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Add then multiply (add tool, multiply tool)
2Ô∏è‚É£ Power fn (add tool, multiply tool)
3Ô∏è‚É£ Dial num then enter (dial tool, enter tool)
4Ô∏è‚É£ Search, dial, enter (search tool, dial tool, enter tool)

replyTo.text:
We tested agents using the OpenAI Function API natively + agents using the ReAct loop.

We evaluated each (agent type, model, task) tuple and reported whether the agent prediction is correct given the task.

activity.text:
In general it seems like there‚Äôs a big drop-off curve of reliability for non GPT-4/Claude v2 models.üìâ

These simple tasks can be a good LLM sanity check before you decide to feed the LLM more complex tools.

Big s/o to @disiok. Please test this out; we're open to contributions!

A big reason why RAG systems fail is due to bad retrieval, not your LLM.

That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs so important to benchmark your retrieval methods! (top-k, reranking, etc.) üß™

BEIR is an awesome benchmark for IR, and you can now use it to benchmark *any* retrieval method in LlamaIndexüëá https://t.co/juhj5xXJAI

@llama_index BEIR is a *zero-shot test* set. It‚Äôs not meant for iterative development‚Äîyou‚Äôre supposed to only touch it *once* after all model selection is completed.

I suggest using an OOD  *dev* set for this, like LoTTE:dev, if you want something people can just ‚Äúcheck‚Äù their methods o n.

Instead: ‚Äúcache‚Äù data and then search üí°. Available in @llama_index üëá https://t.co/EbybycYpW1

The search tool, if called, will then call this index to query for the right result!

Earlier in 2022, @a16z put out a great update to ‚ÄúEmerging Architectures for Modern Data Infrastructure,‚Äù with architecture diagrams detailing the data/AI landscape.

With the rise in LLM‚Äôs/generative AI, it‚Äôs time to think about another update (a small üßµ): https://t.co/tqdyotUYkW

In practice, any enterprise data lake will have both structured and unstructured data. 

We‚Äôve created a tutorial on how LLMs can help you route a query to either a SQL db OR vector db! 

Get structured analytics or semantic search in one package.

Guide: https://t.co/o1T6wqTyP7 https://t.co/0LGGvXSIIV

There are two separate LLM stacks over structured/unstructured data:
- Text-to-SQL (structured)
